questions.stem: A good first step when reading a test question is to:

choices.text: Read the entire question and predict the answer.
Skim quickly and choose the longest option.
Pick the first answer that mentions speed.
Skip any question with signs.

questions.explanation: Predicting the answer helps you evaluate options objectively.

questions.stem: Which option is often a clue that an answer may be wrong?

choices.text: Absolute words like 'always' or 'never' in safety context.
Encouraging defensive driving.
Suggesting more scanning and signaling.
Advising you to slow down for poor conditions.

questions.explanation: Absolutes can be traps; safety decisions depend on conditions.

questions.stem: At a 4-way stop, two vehicles arrive at the same time. Who goes first?

choices.text: The driver on the right.
The driver in the bigger car.
Whoever honks.
Both at once.

questions.explanation: The vehicle on the right has the right-of-way when arriving simultaneously.

questions.stem: Double solid yellow lines between lanes mean:

choices.text: No passing in either direction.
Passing allowed at any time.
Parking only.
Bike lane.

questions.stem: When driving at night or in rain, you should:

choices.text: Increase following distance and slow as needed.
Follow closer to see their taillights.
Use high beams for all oncoming traffic.
Drive the posted maximum regardless of conditions.

questions.explanation: Visibility and traction are reduced; increase space and reduce speed.

questions.stem: You must yield to a pedestrian:

choices.text: In a crosswalk, marked or unmarked, when they are in your path.
Only if they run.
Only when a crossing guard is present.
Only if traffic is stopped behind you.

questions.explanation: Drivers must yield to pedestrians lawfully crossing.

questions.stem: Before your DMV knowledge test, you should:

choices.text: Confirm documents and appointment details.
Skip sleep to study all night.
Forget about ID; it’s optional.
Arrive late to avoid lines.

questions.explanation: Arrive prepared with correct documents and on time.

questions.stem: If you do not pass on your first attempt:

choices.text: Review missed topics and follow retake policies.
Hide your results and retake immediately, regardless of policy.
Stop studying; the test will be easier next time.
Argue until they change the score.

questions.explanation: Use feedback to target weaknesses and comply with retake rules.

choices.text: Patience, respect for others, and planning ahead.
Racing to beat red lights.
Following peers who show off.
Ignoring maintenance to save money.

questions.explanation: Responsible choices reduce risk for everyone.

questions.stem: You may pass another vehicle when:

choices.text: It’s legal (not over double solid lines) and you have sufficient clear distance.
Anytime you feel like it.
In a crosswalk.
On blind curves or hills.

questions.explanation: Pass only when legal and safe with a clear view.

questions.stem: Best practice with phones while driving is to:

choices.text: Avoid handling the phone and use hands-free if needed, or wait.
Text at red lights; it’s always fine.
Hold the phone to your ear at highway speeds.
Watch videos as long as volume is low.

questions.explanation: Minimize distraction: hands-free or wait until parked.

questions.stem: After you earn your permit, the best next step is to:

choices.text: Practice with supervision and review the handbook regularly.
Stop studying entirely.
Drive alone to learn faster.
Ignore maintenance to save time.

questions.explanation: Learning continues with supervised practice and periodic reviews.
